etymologies: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin conjunctio(n-), from the verb conjungere (see conjoin)

definitions: a word used to connect clauses or sentences or to coordinate words in the same clause (e.g. and, but, if).
shortDefinitions: word used to connect clauses or sentences or to coordinate words in same clause

definitions: the action or an instance of two or more events or things occurring at the same point in time or space

examples.text: a conjunction of favorable political and economic circumstances
he postulated that the Americas were formed by the conjunction of floating islands

shortDefinitions: action or instance of two or more events or things occurring at same point

definitions: an alignment of two planets or other celestial objects so that they appear to be in the same, or nearly the same, place in the sky

examples.text: the conjunctions and oppositions of the planets
the planet reached conjunction with the sun

shortDefinitions: alignment of two planets or other celestial objects so that they appear to be in same
